paragraphs.text: %md # OML4R Data Transformation Date Datatypes In this notebook, we demonstrate how to perform various operations on date and time data using database table proxy objects using OML4R. Using a sequence of date and time data spanning from 2001/01/01 to 2001/12/31, we show how to do operations on date and time data. These operations include arithmetic, aggregation, comparisons, accessing details of data, coercion, as well as an example of ARIMA with a rolling mean window function. Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0 ---

msg.data:
OML4R Data Transformation Date Datatypes

In this notebook, we demonstrate how to perform various operations on date and time data using database table proxy objects using OML4R.

Using a sequence of date and time data spanning from 2001/01/01 to 2001/12/31, we show how to do operations on date and time data. These operations include arithmetic, aggregation,
comparisons, accessing details of data, coercion, as well as an example of ARIMA with a rolling mean window function.

Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.title: For more information...
paragraphs.text: %md OML4R documentation on preparing time series data: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/machine-learning/oml4r/1.5.1/oreug/preparing-time-series-data.html

msg.data: OML4R documentation on preparing time series data: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/machine-learning/oml4r/1.5.1/oreug/preparing-time-series-data.html

paragraphs.title: Import R libraries and set seed
Create datetime dataset as a database table with ore.push
paragraphs.text:
%r 

n <- 500

mydata <- data.frame(datetime = seq(as.POSIXct("2001/01/01"), as.POSIXct("2001/12/31"), length.out = n), 
                     difftime = as.difftime(runif(n), units = "mins"), 
                     x = rnorm(n))

MYDATA <- ore.push(mydata) # create temporary table and return proxy object

class(MYDATA)
class(MYDATA$datetime)

z.show(head(MYDATA, 3))

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Create day1Shift dataset by adding 1 day to each date in MYDATA$datetime
paragraphs.text:
%r  

options("width"=200)

day1Shift <- MYDATA$datetime + as.difftime(1, units = "days")

cat(class(day1Shift), "\n")
head(MYDATA$datetime, 3)
cat("\n")
head(day1Shift, 3)

paragraphs.title: Use diff function to get the differences in time between each value of MYDATA$datetime.

%md

# Date and time aggregates

Obtain statistical aggregates of your date and time data.

paragraphs.title: Calculate quantiles at the 0%, 5%, and 10% marks
Use comparison to identify all data that is in Q1
Use comparison and identified Q1 data to identify subset of data that is in March
paragraphs.text:
%r

isMarch <- isQ1 & MYDATA$datetime > as.Date("2001/03/01")
cat(class(isMarch), "\n")
cat(sum(isMarch), "\n")
head(isMarch[70:85,], 100)

paragraphs.text:
%md

# Date and time accessors

Extract various features from your date and time data.

Create a function to extract all details from data given a dataframe DF and column name dates.
After running this function, an attribute importance algorithm can then tell you how impactful these new columns are.

paragraphs.text:
%md

# ARIMA example with rolling mean window function

msg.data: ARIMA example with rolling mean window function

paragraphs.title: Add rolling mean columns to the dataset using functions ore.rollmean and ore.rollsd
paragraphs.text:
%r

row.names(MYDATA) <- MYDATA$datetime
MYDATA$rollmean5 <- ore.rollmean(MYDATA$x, k = 5)

MYDATA$rollsd5 <- ore.rollsd(MYDATA$x, k = 5)

z.show(head(MYDATA))

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Get subset of MYDATA for month of March
ARIMA example on column x
paragraphs.text:
%r

# Use ts function to convert marchData$x to time-series data
tseries.x <- ts(marchData$x)

# Apply arima function to time series data
arima110.x <- arima(tseries.x, c(1,1,0))

# Use arima model to predict 3 periods into the future.
predict(arima110.x, 3)

msg.data:
$pred

  3. 0.737403253131558

paragraphs.title: ARIMA example on column rm5
paragraphs.text:
%r

# Use ts function to convert marchData$rollmean5 to time-series data
tseries.rm5 <- ts(marchData$rollmean5)

# Apply arima function to time series data
arima110.rm5 <- arima(tseries.rm5, c(1,1,0))

# Use arima model to predict 3 periods into the future
predict(arima110.rm5, 3)
